title: Synthetic Recap
body:
ATLANTA (AP) — In a defensive slugfest that felt plucked from a bygone era, the Atlanta Hawks outlasted the Washington Wizards 82-77 in a game that will be remembered not for its final score, but for a singular, Herculean performance that defied belief.

On a night where points were a precious commodity, Dikembe Mutombo didn’t just dominate the paint; he annexed it. The Hawks’ center was an indomitable force, pulling down a staggering **29 rebounds** and swatting away **8 shots**, turning the lane into his personal fortress. Every Washington foray into the key was met with either a rejection that echoed through the arena or a rebound ripped away with authoritative force. While Steve Smith led all scorers with 25 points, his efforts were supplementary to the main event: the Mutombo Show.

The Wizards, led by Chris Webber’s 18 points and 15 rebounds, fought valiantly but found no answer for the league’s premier defensive stalwart. The game was a grind, a possession-by-possession war of attrition where a single basket felt like a monumental achievement. Mutombo’s sheer will on the glass and his rim protection were the decisive factors in a contest where neither team could muster 80 points until the final moments.

In the end, the final margin was five points, but the story was told in one monumental line in the stat sheet. Dikembe Mutombo didn't just win a game for the Hawks; he delivered a historic defensive masterclass, a reminder that greatness on one end of the floor can be every bit as beautiful and game-deciding as any scoring outburst.
